Posts.Content: Hi, I'm afraid aqueous cream is a bit of a bugbear of mine. To find the full information I am posting a link : http://www.eczema.org/aqeous   I know this is the eczema website, but the test described were carried out on people NOT suffering from eczema, so valid for us. My preference is E45, or Sudocrem, but Sudo has lavender in it, so might not be very good for sore/painful skin. Although it is used on babies bottoms!!
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy/Aqueous Cream and damaged skin

Posts.Content: Would Aloe Vera gel help. I bought two 200 ml tubes for £10 from Holland and Barrat. I think it's on offer at the moment. It says suitable for vegetarians and Vegans on the tube. Hope you find a solution. xx
Posts.Title: Any suggestions....

Posts.Content: I started on Anastrazole, but got very itchy so switched to Tamoxifen. I had Wockhardt and Teva, both with no side effects. I now know it wasn't Anastrazole that caused the itching, so I'm hoping my Oncologist is going to put me back on it tomorrow. It didn't cause me any joint problems, and I have RA and Osteopenia among other things. Or maybe I'm so used to the RA that I didn't notice the effects of Anastrazole!!
Posts.Title: tamoxifen different brands

Posts.Content: Hi nuttytart So sorry you have had to join this club  that nobody wants to join. I can promise that once chemo has started, you will find it's not as bad as you expected. I've had two sessions now, one more of Fec, then change to tax for last 3 sessions. I'm not saying it is pleasant, but you will get drugs for the worst side effects like nausea and sickness. Thankfully I haven't had that problem, but in the first few days after I use the anti sickness pills 'just in case' especially if I'm going shopping. As far as hair loss is concerned, the thought of it never bothered me, I'm proudly bald. But the other night I dreamt I put my hat on to go out, when I got back I took my hat off and found I had a head full of beautiful, auburn, shoulder length hair. But when I brushed it, it came out in long thick hanks and lay on the floor around my feet. So what does that say about me then? Incidentally, it won't come out in thick hanks. And if it does start to come out, you will know around day 9 of first cycle, as your scalp will become very tender and sore. But good luck with the cold cap and with chemo in general. Big hugs from Poemsgalore xxx
Posts.Title: New to all this

Posts.Content: Hi sianikb, You don't say whether or not you are taking some kind of hormone tablet, such as Tamoxifen or one of the Aromatase Inhibitors. If you are, it might be worth mentioning it to your consultant as that might be the problem.  poemsgalore xx
Posts.Title: Stupid headaches

Posts.Content: On the days when you have to take steroid tablets, take them early. Don't leave them until mid to late afternoon as they will keep you awake. I used to have first lot with breakfast then second lot with lunch. And good luck xx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Karen, Sorry to hear you are having to go through this. We all find that while we are waiting for various tests/treatments, waiting is the worst time. Hopefully when your treatment starts, you will find everything a little easier to cope with. Do you know what surgery you will have? Are you hormone  or HER2 positive? Do you have lymph node involvement? There are so many questions you need to ask your surgeon/breast care nurse. Take a notebook and pen so you can jot down answers to your questions. Sending hugs and wishing you well.  poemsgalore x
Posts.Title: New to this!

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, just to let you know that I didn't cry at all throughout diagnosis or treatment. But now (just over one year on) I'm scared all the time, and find myself blubbing over the silliest things. As others have said, the build up of emotion as we are rushed through our  various treatments just seems to get the better of us at times. The sleeplessness and bad dreams sounds so familiar to me, that I'm sending extra special big hugs and best wishes. poemsgalore xx
Posts.Title: Nearly 1 year on - why am I crying?

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne I to am on Fec T, but not bothering with Cold Cap. Don't really know whether you can use it with Tax, but I know several ladies who are using it with Fec, with mixed results. This quote from the booklet on Tax might help: "Docetaxel causes hair loss. Most people will lose all their hair,including eyebrows, eyelashes and body hair. You may begin to lose your hair about two weeks after the first treatment, but it can happen earlier. Hair loss is usually gradual but it can happen very quickly, possibly over a couple of days. It can sometimes be minimised by scalp cooling. This involves wearing a ‘cold cap’before, during and for one to two hours after your treatment with chemotherapy drugs. How well the cold cap works depends onthe drugs and doses used, and it does not work for everyone.The hair loss should be temporary and in most cases your hair will begin to grow back a few weeks after your treatment has ended. Prolonged or permanent hair loss has been reported in a very small number of cases." Hope this helps you decide whether to use it on Tax or not. Using it for the Fec part  might help you keep your hair a bit longer if it works. All the best Poemsgalore xx
Posts.Title: Waiting....and waiting.... doesn't it cause more stress?

Posts.Content: This is a brilliant resource, dreamthief, thanks for reminding us. I've downloaded the ones that are relevent to me and have them on my iPad. They can be read in the iBook app on there.  poemsgalore x
Posts.Title: Full Range of Breast Cancer Related Books To Read/Download

Posts.Content: I bought Re Gen oil and also cream, a bit cheaper than Bio Oil, and just has good. My mastectomy scar has faded really well.
Posts.Title: Cheap Bio Oil

Posts.Content: Yes, it's fine for showering with. I just wanted you to be aware of the risks of using it as a moisturiser. I would suggest E45, But it is up to you. xx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - Help please

Posts.Content: May I just mention. Aqueous cream is no longer advised to be used as a moisturizer. Just  a soap replacement. It contains a substance called Sodium Lauryl Sulfate. This is what 'Natural News' says about it: "Sodium lauryl sulfate (SLS) is a chemical lathering agent that has come under scrutiny for safety and potential toxicity issues. It is found in a large amount of the products we use every day for personal hygiene and body care. Among them are toothpaste, shampoo, lotions, soap, liquid body and facial cleansers, and more. Sodium lauryl sulfate did not start off as a detergent that was meant for use in consumer products. It was initially sold as an industrial strength detergent primarily used for heavy duty cleaners and degreasers. It is now found in products which are in close and frequent contact with human skin. SLS strips the hair and skin of moisture because of its strong detergent properties. You can actually get your skin, mouth and hair just as clean using gentler, more skin and membrane-friendly substances. There are several fatty acids that work to cleanse the skin without disrupting the delicate acid mantle that protects it from outside elements and toxins. Sodium lauryl sulfate has been identified as one of the primary skin irritants that are used in body care products today. It has the ability to easily penetrate the dermal layers and enter the blood stream. The caustic lathering agent easily destroys the lipid layers that keep the skin smooth and supple." poemsgalore
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - Help please

Posts.Content: I'll try and remember that tip when I finally get put on it, thank you jeniLondon
Posts.Title: Side effects with Anastrozole (Armidex)

Posts.Content: Thanks for that advice KateG, I will eventually be put on Anastrazole after chemo and possibly rads, so I'm glad of any info from those using it already. Poemsgalore
Posts.Title: Side effects with Anastrozole (Armidex)

Posts.Content: Hi Bobbydazzler, Perhaps while you are doing your jobs around the house, you could stick your iPod or MP3 player on to take your mind of your worries. We can't have you toppling over the ironing board can we.  Sending hugs poemsgalore xx
Posts.Title: Weird & Wobbly

Posts.Content: Hi Fissi I was dx with ductal invasive ER+ PR+, HER2- and had mx with three nodes removed, one affected by cancer. Just finished chemo and discussed rads with my onco. She told me less than 20% chance of recurrence in chest and 50% chance in axillary (armpit) which could be sorted by axillary clearance if necessary. I'm not having rads at all and just moving straight on to hormone tablet (possibly Anastrazole) See if you can find out what percentage you have of recurrence before making decision about rads. I do realise that because you had WLE and not mx, your percentage of recurrence might be a bit higher than mine. Good Luck. Poemsgalore xx
Posts.Title: Any Advice

Posts.Content: Hello, sorry to hear of your mum's diagnosis. Cancer in the lymph nodes isn't secondary cancer thankfully, because I had cancer in one of my lymph nodes too. Secondary breast cancer is when it spreads beyond the breast and local lymph nodes, into either the bones, brain, liver or lungs. So breathe a sigh of relief.  Sending hugs and best wishes for the radiotherapy. poemsgalore xx By the way, I tried to accept your friend request but it didn't seem to work. So I'll send one to you and see if it works that way instead. xx
Posts.Title: BREAST CANCER - INFO ON SENTINEL NODE BIOPSY RESULTS

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with breast cancer in November 2012. I was told it was ductal invasive, nst. I understand this as I've read all about it. But I recently received  a print out of my full diagnosis which said "ductal nst, lobular" I wondered what exactly this meant. Anyone explain please?? poemsgalore
Posts.Title: Confused now

Posts.Content: I started Anastrazole last July. Stopped it for one month as we thought it might be causing my awful itching - it wasn't. Onco put me on Tamoxifen for a while but now I'm back on Anastrazole and have been taking it for one month. This last couple of weeks I've had on and off light bleeding (no pain). I have read that this can happen after swapping hormone treatments so not too worried. Has anyone had this and if so, how long did the bleeding last? I'm 63 and at least 10 years past the menopause. Thank you in advance.  poemsgalore x
Posts.Title: Bleeding on Anastrazole

Posts.Content: Hi HilaryAnne My situation was similar to yours, tumour 3cm, Grade 3, but was ER+, PR+, HER2-. Three nodes removed, one of which was affected by cancer. By choice I am having chemo. Originally FEC-T, but my one and only experience of TAX was a bit of a disaster so my oncologist has put me back on FEC. I don't think any of the side effects of chemo are long term. Once the treatments are over, apart from tiredness for a while, you should go back to being pretty well normal. Whatever your decision, good luck.
Posts.Title: Chemo decision, advice required

Posts.Content: Thanks chrisdarl. I have an appointment with my oncologist at the end of September, if it hasn't cleared up by then I will tell her and see what she thinks. It's not heavy, but a little more than spotting, and only late afternoon/early evening. Just a bit of a nuisance really. x
Posts.Title: Bleeding on Anastrazole

Posts.Content: Hi, just found out someone I know who also has breast cancer has vascular invasion. Does anyone know anything about this?
Posts.Title: Vascular Invasion

Posts.Content: Hi Twirly So sorry I never got back to you to thank you for your reply. My friend was having chemo, so she should be ok thanks. Three quarters of the way through MY chemo, I discovered that I too had Vascular Invasion. I had 5 rounds of FEC and 1 of TAX. What worried me, was that I hadn't been told before about this, but when offered chemo, I was told that I didn't have to have chemo if I didn't want to. While that is all well and good, what if I'd said 'no' and then found out about the vascular invasion?? I would have been really worried -no, scared!! Thank you again for your reply  - that's if you find my very late reply. Hope you continue to be clear and well. Poemsgalore xxx
Posts.Title: Vascular Invasion

Posts.Content: Hi all, I was DX with grade 3 ductal invasive on November 1st 2012 but didn't have my mastectomy and SNB until 12th December 2012. I had chemo between 5th February - 223rd May 2013. Now on Anastrazole for at least 5 years, and as you can see by the dates have already had one annual mammogram/breast check. Wishing you all the very best for your treatment. poemsgalore xx
Posts.Title: scared and angry

Posts.Content: Hi, I don't have low blood pressure, quite the opposite, I take Felodopine for high blood pressure. I'm just about to have Fec 2, but noticed after the first one, I felt dizzy in the mornings. I found taking an anti-sickness tablet seemed to make it go away. Hope you sort this out soon Hannah.
Posts.Title: hiya I'm hannah and new to this site

Posts.Content: I usually find mine on the top of my head - which is where I always put them when not actually using them. But do I ever remember? Course not!!
Posts.Title: doh!

Posts.Content: Fec 2 went well thank you Hannah. One more and I change to Tax for the last three, so new worries for me and probably new side effects too. Hope all goes well with your CT scan.
Posts.Title: hiya I'm hannah and new to this site

Posts.Content: Just wanted to say hi, and good luck with FEC. I seemed to sail through FEC with minimal side effects. Hope you do too. xx
Posts.Title: Chemo starting

Posts.Content: Hi, I had Mx on December 12th 2012. I had my first mammogram on remaining breast in December 2013, but in January 2014 I had a full breast check where they did a physical check on scar tissue and lymph nodes both beneath my arm and up to clavicle, then did the same to my 'healthy' breast and lymph nodes. But I'm worried about what happens after the five years annual checks. When they put me back on a mammogram every three years? They won't check my affected side then, surely it will be up to me??
Posts.Title: Mammogram after mx?

Posts.Content: The one that to me is the most dangerous, is when someone under the age of 50 (anything up to 30) is told by GP "You're too young to have breast cancer, go home and stop being paranoid"!! OK, so it's more common among us older lasses (I was 61 when diagnosed) but it does happen to women very much younger, sadly!!
Posts.Title: Most outrageous, ridiculous etc

Posts.Content: Oh I've heard that one too. A chap on a different forum who had a totally unrelated cancer was actually giving advice to a petrified woman about breast cancer. He told her: "Breast cancer is just like any other long term conditions nowadays"! Boy, did I give him a chewing over!! A funnier story. I had a mastectomy with no recon. The first time my dippy neighbour saw me with my (hated) prosthesis in, she said: "Oh! has it grown back again??" Doh!
Posts.Title: Most outrageous, ridiculous etc

Posts.Content: Hi Cbaz, My cancer was also Ductal Invasive, 100% ER + 70% PR +, HER2 - After my mastectomy and SNB I found it was 36mm, grade 3, stage 2b. Three lymph nodes removed, one with cancer. I was offered chemo but told if I didn't want it I didn't have to have it because of several serious health problems. I took it and got through pretty well considering. I was neutropenic once and in hospital because of it, but my side effects weren't too bad really. I had no nausea or sickness and only had six days in the cycle where I felt a bit rough (wiped out and very flaky). That was last February-May. So don't be too scared if you do have to have chemo. Radiotherapy was my big fear as I have a lung condition. I didn't have any radio but I'm taking Anastrazole now.
Posts.Title: When and why would you have chemo..

Posts.Content: Hi margr20, When you go to see the oncologist (who is in charge of hormone tablet) ask what percentage of benefit you will gain by taking the tablet. My cancer was 100% Oestrogen positive and 70% Progesterone positive, so it was a no brainer for me. I am taking Anastrazole for at least 5 years. Personally, if I was 'in the middle' I would err on the side of caution and still take the tablet and see how I got on regarding side effects.  xxx
Posts.Title: hormone treatment
